_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

CHS - Rochelle (formerly Illinois River Energy, LLC) operates a fuel ethanol plant located in Rochelle, Ogle County, Illinois.  The plant is permitted to produce 133 million gallons of denatured ethanol per year.  In accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency's Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions at Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, CHS - Rochelle has completed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for covered processes that contain an RMP listed toxic or flammable substance at a quantity exceeding the corresponding program applicability threshold. 



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

CHS - Rochelle is committed to the protection of its employees, the community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process specifically pentane as a constituent of the natural gasoline used as the ethanol denaturant to make the fuel ethanol unfit for human consumption.  It is the policy of CHS - Rochelle to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  In the event of an emergency, including an accidental release of natural gasoline, it is the policy of CHS - Rochelle to notify the National Response Center, Illinois Emergency Management Agency, and the Local Emergency Planning Committees for Ogle County, Illinois, and to evacuate all non-essential employees and all visitors from the facility.



Regulated Substances Handled

The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and a process by-product known as dry distillers grain with solubles, which is used as a livestock feed.  The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (natural gasoline) which is reported to contain up to 30 percent pentane, up to 30 percent isopentane, and up to 5 percent butane, which are RMP regulated flammable substances.  The maximum amount of natural gasoline on-site is estimated to be approximately 1,032,075 pounds (lbs) including approximately 30

9,623 lbs of pentane, 309,623 lbs of isopentane, and 51,604 lbs of butane.  The natural gasoline is stored in a 165,000-gallon above ground floating roof bulk liquid storage tank and is introduced to the 200-proof ethanol in the final stage of production.  The denaturant tank is located in the facility's tank farm containment area which consists of secondary containment berm and impervious synthetic liner.  

CHS - Rochelle stores anhydrous ammonia, an RMP regulated toxic substance, in an 18,000-gallon bulk liquid storage tank and used in the ethanol production process for pH control.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored on site is estimated to be 86,600 lbs.   CHS - Rochelle has evaluated the worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the reportable substances.  An emergency response program for these scenarios has been prepared and implemented.  CHS - Rochelle has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities and conducts periodic emergency response drills.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, CHS - Rochelle has complied with the EPA Chemical Accident Prevention requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 and the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119 for the denaturant and anhydrous ammonia storage tanks and handling systems.  Process safety information and operations/maintenance procedures are documented on-site.  Periodic functions such as process hazard analyses, employee emergency response and process operations training, management of change reviews, and process safety inspections are conducted on a regular basis.  Audits of the overall RMP will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA regulations.



Five Year Accident History

CHS - Rochelle (formerly Illinois River Energy, LLC) does not have a history of accidents which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, ev
acuations or in-place sheltering in the past five years.
